content: AMBER Alert: 21 Years of Progress in Recovering Abducted Children

tag: html body div div div div div p span
content: Today, the AMBER Alert system is being used in all 50 states, the District of Columbia, Indian country, Puerto Rico, the U.S. Virgin Islands, and 22 other countries. As of March 2018, a total of 924 children had been successfully recovered through the AMBER Alert system.

tag: html body div div div div div p strong span
content: AMBER Alerts will link to photos of missing children under FCC upgrades.

tag: html body div div div div div p span
content: On September 29, 2016, the Federal Communications Commission (FCC)

tag: html body div div div div div p a span
html body div div div div div p span
content: to Wireless Emergency Alerts (WEA), a system that delivers critical warnings and information to wireless phone users. The FCC updates are intended to enhance the information state and local authorities are able to send into communities. The changes include requiring wireless providers to support inclusion of embedded phone numbers and URLs in all WEA alerts, including allowing users to link to pictures and phone numbers in AMBER Alert urgent child-abduction bulletins. The new FCC rules are planned to be implemented within the next 30 months.

tag: html body div div div div div p span
content: The AMBER AlertT Program is a voluntary partnership between law-enforcement agencies, broadcasters, transportation agencies, and the wireless industry, to activate an urgent bulletin in the most serious child-abduction cases. The goal of an AMBER Alert is to instantly galvanize the entire community to assist in the search for and the safe recovery of the child.
